data.text: A large leather suitcase that opens into two hinged compartments.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A word formed by merging the sounds and meanings of two different words, as chortle, from chuckle and snort.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A word or part of a word that is analyzable as consisting of more than one morpheme without a clear boundary between them, as French du “of the” from de “of” and le “the.”
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A case used in journeying for containing clothing: originally adapted to the saddle of a horseman, and therefore nearly cylindrical and of flexible make.
A trunk, especially a leather trunk of small size.
A hook or bracket on which to hang a garment, especially one which holds a coat or cloak securely for brushing.
A bag or case, usually of leather, for carrying wearing apparel, etc., on journeys.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: A large <xref>travelling</xref> <xref>case</xref> usually made of <xref>leather</xref>, and opening into two equal sections.
